Low-density graph codes that are optimal for source/channel coding and binning

Martin J. Wainwright Emin Martinian
Dept. of Statistics, and Tilda Consulting, Inc.
Dept. of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences Arlington, MA
University of California, Berkeley emin@alum.mit.edu
wainwrig@{eecs,stat}.berkeley.edu

Technical Report 730,

Department of Statistics, UC Berkeley,

April 2007

Abstract

We describe and analyze the joint source/channel coding properties of a class of sparse graphical codes based on compounding a low-density generator matrix (LDGM) code with a low-density parity check (LDPC) code. Our first pair of theorems establish that there exist codes from this ensemble, with all degrees remaining bounded independently of block length, that are simultaneously optimal as both source and channel codes when encoding and decoding are performed optimally. More precisely, in the context of lossy compression, we prove that finite degree constructions can achieve any pair (R,D)ğ‘…ğ·(R,D) on the rate-distortion curve of the binary symmetric source. In the context of channel coding, we prove that finite degree codes can achieve any pair (C,p)ğ¶ğ‘(C,p) on the capacity-noise curve of the binary symmetric channel. Next, we show that our compound construction has a nested structure that can be exploited to achieve the Wyner-Ziv bound for source coding with side information (SCSI), as well as the Gelfand-Pinsker bound for channel coding with side information (CCSI). Although the current results are based on optimal encoding and decoding, the proposed graphical codes have sparse structure and high girth that renders them well-suited to message-passing and other efficient decoding procedures.

Keywords: Graphical codes; low-density parity check code (LDPC); low-density generator matrix code (LDGM); weight enumerator; source coding; channel coding; Wyner-Ziv problem; Gelfand-Pinsker problem; coding with side information; information embedding; distributed source coding.

1 Introduction

Over the past decade, codes based on graphical constructions, including turbo codesÂ [3] and low-density parity check (LDPC) codesÂ [17], have proven extremely successful for channel coding problems. The sparse graphical nature of these codes makes them very well-suited to decoding using efficient message-passing algorithms, such as the sum-product and max-product algorithms. The asymptotic behavior of iterative decoding on graphs with high girth is well-characterized by the density evolution methodÂ [25, 39], which yields a useful design principle for choosing degree distributions. Overall, suitably designed LDPC codes yield excellent practical performance under iterative message-passing, frequently very close to Shannon limitsÂ [7].

However, many other communication problems involve aspects of lossy source coding, either alone or in conjunction with channel coding, the latter case corresponding to joint source-channel coding problems. Well-known examples include lossy source coding with side information (one variant corresponding to the Wyner-Ziv problemÂ [45]), and channel coding with side information (one variant being the Gelfand-Pinsker problemÂ [19]). The information-theoretic schemes achieving the optimal rates for coding with side information involve delicate combinations of source and channel coding. For problems of this natureâ€”in contrast to the case of pure channel codingâ€”the use of sparse graphical codes and message-passing algorithm is not nearly as well understood. With this perspective in mind, the focus of this paper is the design and analysis sparse graphical codes for lossy source coding, as well as joint source/channel coding problems. Our main contribution is to exhibit classes of graphical codes, with all degrees remaining bounded independently of the blocklength, that simultaneously achieve the information-theoretic bounds for both source and channel coding under optimal encoding and decoding.

1.1 Previous and ongoing work

A variety of code architectures have been suggested for lossy compression and related problems in source/channel coding. One standard approach to lossy compression is via trellis-code quantization (TCQ)Â [26]. The advantage of trellis constructions is that exact encoding and decoding can be performed using the max-product or Viterbi algorithmÂ [24], with complexity that grows linearly in the trellis length but exponentially in the constraint length. Various researchers have exploited trellis-based codes both for single-source and distributed compressionÂ [6, 23, 37, 46] as well as information embedding problemsÂ [5, 15, 42]. One limitation of trellis-based approaches is the fact that saturating rate-distortion bounds requires increasing the trellis constraint lengthÂ [43], which incurs exponential complexity (even for the max-product or sum-product message-passing algorithms).

Other researchers have proposed and studied the use of low-density parity check (LDPC) codes and turbo codes, which have proven extremely successful for channel coding, in application to various types of compression problems. These techniques have proven particularly successful for lossless distributed compression, often known as the Slepian-Wolf problemÂ [18, 40]. An attractive feature is that the source encoding step can be transformed to an equivalent noisy channel decoding problem, so that known constructions and iterative algorithms can be leveraged. For lossy compression, other workÂ [31] shows that it is possible to approach the binary rate-distortion bound using LDPC-like codes, albeit with degrees that grow logarithmically with the blocklength.

A parallel line of work has studied the use of low-density generator matrix (LDGM) codes, which correspond to the duals of LDPC codes, for lossy compression problemsÂ [30, 44, 9, 35, 34]. Focusing on binary erasure quantization (a special compression problem dual to binary erasure channel coding), Martinian and YedidiaÂ [30] proved that LDGM codes combined with modified message-passing can saturate the associated rate-distortion bound. Various researchers have used techniques from statistical physics, including the cavity method and replica methods, to provide non-rigorous analyses of LDGM performance for lossy compression of binary sourcesÂ [8, 9, 35, 34]. In the limit of zero-distortion, this analysis has been made rigorous in a sequence of papersÂ [12, 32, 10, 14]. Moreover, our own recent workÂ [28, 27] provides rigorous upper bounds on the effective rate-distortion function of various classes of LDGM codes. In terms of practical algorithms for lossy binary compression, researchers have explored variants of the sum-product algorithmÂ [34] or survey propagation algorithmsÂ [8, 44] for quantizing binary sources.

1.2 Our contributions

Classical random coding argumentsÂ [11] show that random binary linear codes will achieve both channel capacity and rate-distortion bounds. The challenge addressed in this paper is the design and analysis of codes with bounded graphical complexity, meaning that all degrees in a factor graph representation of the code remain bounded independently of blocklength. Such sparsity is critical if there is any hope to leverage efficient message-passing algorithms for encoding and decoding. With this context, the primary contribution of this paper is the analysis of sparse graphical code ensembles in which a low-density generator matrix (LDGM) code is compounded with a low-density parity check (LDPC) code (seeÂ Fig.Â 2 for an illustration). Related compound constructions have been considered in previous work, but focusing exclusively on channel codingÂ [16, 36, 41]. In contrast, this paper focuses on communication problems in which source coding plays an essential role, including lossy compression itself as well as joint source/channel coding problems. Indeed, the source coding analysis of the compound construction requires techniques fundamentally different from those used in channel coding analysis. We also note that the compound code illustrated inÂ Fig.Â 2 can be applied to more general memoryless channels and sources; however, so as to bring the primary contribution into sharp focus, this paper focuses exclusively on binary sources and/or binary symmetric channels.

More specifically, our first pair of theorems establish that for any rate Râˆˆ(0,1)ğ‘…01R\in(0,1), there exist codes from compound LDGM/LDPC ensembles with all degrees remaining bounded independently of the blocklength that achieve both the channel capacity and the rate-distortion bound. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first demonstration of code families with bounded graphical complexity that are simultaneously optimal for both source and channel coding. Building on these results, we demonstrate that codes from our ensemble have a naturally â€œnestedâ€ structure, in which good channel codes can be partitioned into a collection of good source codes, and vice versa. By exploiting this nested structure, we prove that codes from our ensembles can achieve the information-theoretic limits for the binary versions of both the problem of lossy source coding with side information (SCSI, known as the Wyner-Ziv problemÂ [45]), and channel coding with side information (CCSI, known as the Gelfand-PinskerÂ [19] problem). Although these results are based on optimal encoding and decoding, a code drawn randomly from our ensembles will, with high probability, have high girth and good expansion, and hence be well-suited to message-passing and other efficient decoding procedures.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. SectionÂ 2 contains basic background material and definitions for source and channel coding, and factor graph representations of binary linear codes. In SectionÂ 3, we define the ensembles of compound codes that are the primary focus of this paper, and state (without proof) our main results on their source and channel coding optimality. In SectionÂ 4, we leverage these results to show that our compound codes can achieve the information-theoretic limits for lossy source coding with side information (SCSI), and channel coding with side information (CCSI). SectionsÂ 5 andÂ 6 are devoted to proofs that codes from the compound ensemble are optimal for lossy source coding (SectionÂ 5) and channel coding (SectionÂ 6) respectively. We conclude the paper with a discussion in SectionÂ 7. Portions of this work have previously appeared as conference papersÂ [28, 29, 27].

2 Background

In this section, we provide relevant background material on source and channel coding, binary linear codes, as well as factor graph representations of such codes.

2.2 Factor graphs and graphical codes

Both the channel decoding and source encoding problems, if viewed naively, require searching over an exponentially large codebook (since |â„‚|=2nâ€‹Râ„‚superscript2ğ‘›ğ‘…|\mathbb{C}|=2^{nR} for a code of rate Rğ‘…R). Therefore, any practically useful code must have special structure that facilitates decoding and encoding operations. The success of a large subclass of modern codes in use today, especially low-density parity check (LDPC) codesÂ [17, 38], is based on the sparsity of their associated factor graphs.

Given a binary linear code â„‚â„‚\mathbb{C}, specified by parity check matrix Hğ»H, the code structure can be captured by a bipartite graph, in which circular nodes (âˆ˜\circ) represent the binary values xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} (or columns of Hğ»H), and square nodes (â– â– \blacksquare) represent the parity checks (or rows of Hğ»H). For instance, Fig.Â 1(a) shows the factor graph for a rate R=12R12\mathrm{R}=\frac{1}{2} code in parity check form, with m=6ğ‘š6m=6 checks acting on n=12ğ‘›12n=12 bits. The edges in this graph correspond to 111â€™s in the parity check matrix, and reveal the subset of bits on which each parity check acts. The parity check code in Fig.Â 1(a) is a regular code with bit degree 333 and check degree 666. Such low-density constructions, meaning that both the bit degrees and check degrees remain bounded independently of the block length nğ‘›n, are of most practical use, since they can be efficiently represented and stored, and yield excellent performance under message-passing decoding. In the context of a channel coding problem, the shaded circular nodes at the top of the low-density parity check (LDPC) code in panel (a) represent the observed variables yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i} received from the noisy channel.

FigureÂ 1(b) shows a binary linear code represented in factor graph form by its generator matrix GğºG. In this dual representation, each codeword xâˆˆ{0,1}nğ‘¥superscript01ğ‘›x\in\{0,1\}^{n} is generated by taking the matrix-vector product of the form Gâ€‹zğºğ‘§Gz, where zâˆˆ{0,1}mğ‘§superscript01ğ‘šz\in\{0,1\}^{m} is a sequence of information bits, and Gâˆˆ{0,1}nÃ—mğºsuperscript01ğ‘›ğ‘šG\in\{0,1\}^{n\times m} is the generator matrix. For the code shown in panel (b), the blocklength is n=12ğ‘›12n=12, and information sequences are of length m=9ğ‘š9m=9, for an overall rate of R=m/n=0.75ğ‘…ğ‘šğ‘›0.75R=m/n=0.75 in this case. The degrees of the check and variable nodes in the factor graph are dc=3subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘3d_{c}=3 and dv=4subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘£4d_{v}=4 respectively, so that the associated generator matrix GğºG has dc=3subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘3d_{c}=3 ones in each row, and dv=4subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘£4d_{v}=4 ones in each column. When the generator matrix is sparse in this setting, then the resulting code is known as a low-density generator matrix (LDGM) code.

3 Optimality of bounded degree compound constructions

In this section, we describe the compound LDGM/LDPC construction that is the focus of this paper, and describe our main results on their source and channel coding optimality.

3.1 Compound construction

Our main focus is the construction illustrated inÂ Fig.Â 2, obtained by compounding an LDGM code (top two layers) with an LDPC code (bottom two layers). The code is defined by a factor graph with three layers: at the top, a vector xâˆˆ{0,1}nğ‘¥superscript01ğ‘›x\in\{0,1\}^{n} of codeword bits is connected to a set of nğ‘›n parity checks, which are in turn connected by a sparse generator matrix GğºG to a vector yâˆˆ{0,1}mğ‘¦superscript01ğ‘šy\in\{0,1\}^{m} of information bits in the middle layer. The information bits yğ‘¦y are also codewords in an LDPC code, defined by the parity check matrix Hğ»H connecting the middle and bottom layers.

In more detail, considering first the LDGM component of the compound code, each codeword xâˆˆ{0,1}nğ‘¥superscript01ğ‘›x\in\{0,1\}^{n} in the top layer is connected via the generator matrix Gâˆˆ{0,1}nÃ—mğºsuperscript01ğ‘›ğ‘šG\in\{0,1\}^{n\times m} to an information sequence yâˆˆ{0,1}mğ‘¦superscript01ğ‘šy\in\{0,1\}^{m} in the middle layer; more specifically, we have the algebraic relation x=Gâ€‹yğ‘¥ğºğ‘¦x=Gy. Note that this LDGM code has rate RGâ‰¤mnsubscriptğ‘…ğºğ‘šğ‘›R_{G}\leq\frac{m}{n}. Second, turning to the LDPC component of the compound construction, its codewords correspond to a subset of information sequences yâˆˆ{0,1}mğ‘¦superscript01ğ‘šy\in\{0,1\}^{m} in the middle layer. In particular, any valid codeword yğ‘¦y satisfies the parity check relation Hâ€‹y=0ğ»ğ‘¦0Hy=0, where Hâˆˆ{0,1}mÃ—kğ»superscript01ğ‘šğ‘˜H\in\{0,1\}^{m\times k} joins the middle and bottom layers of the construction. Overall, this defines an LDPC code with rate RH=1âˆ’kmsubscriptğ‘…ğ»1ğ‘˜ğ‘šR_{H}=1-\frac{k}{m}, assuming that Hğ»H has full row rank.

The overall code â„‚â„‚\mathbb{C} obtained by concatenating the LDGM and LDPC codes has blocklength nğ‘›n, and rate Rğ‘…R upper bounded by RGâ€‹RHsubscriptğ‘…ğºsubscriptğ‘…ğ»R_{G}R_{H}. In algebraic terms, the code â„‚â„‚\mathbb{C} is defined as

â„‚â„‚\displaystyle\mathbb{C} :=:absent\displaystyle:\,= {xâˆˆ{0,1}nâˆ£x=Gâ€‹yfor someÂ yâˆˆ{0,1}mÂ such thatHâ€‹y=0},conditional-setğ‘¥superscript01ğ‘›formulae-sequenceğ‘¥ğºğ‘¦for someÂ yâˆˆ{0,1}mÂ such thatğ»ğ‘¦0\displaystyle\left\{x\in\{0,1\}^{n}\;\mid\;x=Gy\quad\mbox{for some $y\in\{0,1\}^{m}$ such that}\quad Hy=0\right\}, (4)

where all operations are in modulo two arithmetic.

Our analysis in this paper will be performed over random ensembles of compound LDGM/LDPC ensembles. In particular, for each degree triplet (dc,dv,dcâ€²)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}), we focus on the following random ensemble:

  1. (a)

    For each fixed integer dcâ‰¥4subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘4d_{c}\geq 4, the random generator matrix Gâˆˆ{0,1}nÃ—mğºsuperscript01ğ‘›ğ‘šG\in\{0,1\}^{n\times m} is specified as follows: for each of the nğ‘›n rows, we choose dcsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘d_{c} positions with replacement, and put a 111 in each of these positions. This procedure yields a random matrix with at most dcsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘d_{c} ones per row, since it is possible (although of asymptotically negligible probability for any fixed dcsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘d_{c}) that the same position is chosen more than once.

  2. (b)

    For each fixed degree pair (dv,dcâ€²)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘(d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}), the random LDPC matrix Hâˆˆ{0,1}kÃ—mğ»superscript01ğ‘˜ğ‘šH\in\{0,1\}^{k\times m} is chosen uniformly at random from the space of all matrices with exactly dvsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘£d_{v} ones per column, and exactly dcâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘d^{\prime}_{c} ones per row. This ensemble is a standard (dv,dcâ€²)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘(d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c})-regular LDPC ensemble.

We note that our reason for choosing the check-regular LDGM ensemble specified in step (a) is not that it need define a particularly good code, but rather that it is convenient for theoretical purposes. Interestingly, our analysis shows that the bounded degree dcsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘d_{c} check-regular LDGM ensemble, even though it is sub-optimal for both source and channel coding in isolationÂ [28, 29], defines optimal source and channel codes when combined with a bottom LDPC code.

3.2 Main results

Our first main result is on the achievability of the Shannon rate-distortion bound using codes from LDGM/LDPC compound construction with finite degrees (dc,dv,dcâ€²)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}). In particular, we make the following claim:

Theorem 1.

Given any pair (R,D)ğ‘…ğ·(R,D) satisfying the Shannon bound, there is a set of finite degrees (dc,dv,dcâ€²)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) and a code from the associated LDGM/LDPC ensemble with rate Rğ‘…R that is a Dğ·D-good source code (see DefinitionÂ 1).

In other workÂ [28, 27], we showed that standard LDGM codes from the check-regular ensemble cannot achieve the rate-distortion bound with finite degrees. As will be highlighted by the proof of TheoremÂ 1 in SectionÂ 5, the inclusion of the LDPC lower code in the compound construction plays a vital role in the achievability of the Shannon rate-distortion curve.

Our second main result of this result is complementary in nature to TheoremÂ 1, regarding the achievability of the Shannon channel capacity using codes from LDGM/LDPC compound construction with finite degrees (dc,dv,dcâ€²)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}). In particular, we have:

Theorem 2.

For all rate-noise pairs (R,p)ğ‘…ğ‘(R,p) satisfying the Shannon channel coding bound R<1âˆ’hâ€‹(p)ğ‘…1â„ğ‘R<1-h\left(p\right), there is a set of finite degrees (dc,dv,dcâ€²)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) and a code from the associated LDGM/LDPC ensemble with rate Rğ‘…R that is a pğ‘p-good channel code (see DefinitionÂ 1).

To put this result into perspective, recall that the overall rate of this compound construction is given by R=RGâ€‹RHğ‘…subscriptğ‘…ğºsubscriptğ‘…ğ»R=R_{G}R_{H}. Note that an LDGM code on its own (i.e., without the lower LDPC code) is a special case of this construction with RH=1subscriptğ‘…ğ»1R_{H}=1. However, a standard LDGM of this variety is not a good channel code, due to the large number of low-weight codewords. Essentially, the proof of TheoremÂ 2 (see SectionÂ 6) shows that using a non-trivial LDPC lower code (with RH<1subscriptğ‘…ğ»1R_{H}<1) can eliminate these troublesome low-weight codewords.

4 Consequences for coding with side information

We now turn to consideration of the consequences of our two main results for problems of coding with side information. It is well-known from previous workÂ [47] that achieving the information-theoretic limits for these problems requires nested constructions, in which a collection of good source codes are nested inside a good channel code (or vice versa). Accordingly, we begin in SectionÂ 4.1 by describing how our compound construction naturally generates such nested ensembles. In SectionsÂ 4.2 andÂ 4.3 respectively, we discuss how the compound construction can be used to achieve the information-theoretic optimum for binary source coding with side information (a version of the Wyner-Ziv problemÂ [45]), and binary information embedding (a version of â€œdirty paper codingâ€, or the Gelfand-Pinsker problemÂ [19]).

4.2 Source coding with side information

We begin by showing that the compound construction can be used to perform source coding with side information (SCSI).

4.2.1 Problem formulation

Suppose that we wish to compress a symmetric Bernoulli source Sâˆ¼Berâ¡(12)similar-toğ‘†Ber12S\sim\operatorname{Ber}(\frac{1}{2}) so as to be able to reconstruct it with Hamming distortion Dğ·D. For this binary version of source coding with side information (SCSI), it is knownÂ [2] that the minimum achievable rate takes the form

RWZâ€‹(D,p)=l.c.e.â¡{hâ€‹(Dâˆ—p)âˆ’hâ€‹(D),(p,0)},\displaystyle R_{\operatorname{WZ}}(D,p)=\operatorname{l.c.e.}\big{\{}h\left(D\ast p\right)-h\left(D\right),\,(p,0)\big{\}}, (8)

In the discussion to follow, we focus only on achieving rates of the form hâ€‹(Dâˆ—p)âˆ’hâ€‹(D)â„âˆ—ğ·ğ‘â„ğ·h\left(D\ast p\right)-h\left(D\right), as any remaining rates on the Wyner-Ziv curveÂ (8) can be achieved by time-sharing with the point (p,0)ğ‘0(p,0).

4.3 Channel coding with side information

We now show how the compound construction can be used to perform channel coding with side information (CCSI).

Consequently, we may set the channel input Vğ‘‰V equal to the quantization noise (V=Eğ‘‰ğ¸V=E), thereby ensuring that the average channel constraintÂ (12) is satisfied.

Step #2, Channel coding: In the second phase, the decoder is given a noisy channel observation of the form

Zğ‘\displaystyle Z =\displaystyle= EâŠ•SâŠ•W=S^âŠ•W,direct-sumğ¸ğ‘†ğ‘Šdirect-sum^ğ‘†ğ‘Š\displaystyle E\oplus S\oplus W\;=\;\widehat{S}\oplus W, (16)

and its task is to recover S^^ğ‘†\widehat{S}. In terms of the code architecture, the k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} lower parity bits remain set to zero; the remaining k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2} parity bits, which represent the message ğ¦ğ¦\mathbf{m}, are unknown to the coder. The resulting code, as illustrated illustrated inÂ Fig.Â 6(b), can be viewed as channel code with effective rate mâˆ’k1nğ‘šsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›\frac{m-k_{1}}{n}. Now suppose that we choose k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} such that the effective code used by the decoder has rate

R2subscriptR2\displaystyle\mathrm{R}_{2} =\displaystyle= mâˆ’k1n=1âˆ’hâ€‹(p)âˆ’Ïµ/2,ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›1â„ğ‘italic-Ïµ2\displaystyle\frac{m-k_{1}}{n}=1-h\left(p\right)-\epsilon/2, (17)

for some Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0. Since the channel noise Wğ‘ŠW is Berâ¡(p)Berğ‘\operatorname{Ber}(p) and the rate R2subscriptR2\mathrm{R}_{2} chosen according toÂ (17), TheoremÂ 2 guarantees that the decoder will w.h.p. be able to recover the pair S^^ğ‘†\widehat{S} and Y^^ğ‘Œ\widehat{Y}. Moreover, by design of the quantization procedure, we have the equivalence ğ¦=H2â€‹Y^ğ¦subscriptğ»2^ğ‘Œ\mathbf{m}=H_{2}\,\widehat{Y} so that a simple syndrome-forming procedure allows the decoder to recover the hidden message.

Summarizing our findings, we state the following:

Corollary 2.

There exist finite choices of degrees (dc,dv,dcâ€²)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) such that the compound LDGM/LDPC construction achieves the binary information embedding (Gelfand-Pinsker) bound.

Proof.

With the source coding rate R1subscriptR1\mathrm{R}_{1} chosen according to equationÂ (15), the encoder will return a quantization S^^ğ‘†\widehat{S} of the host signal Sğ‘†S with average Hamming distortion upper bounded by wğ‘¤w. Consequently, transmitting the quantization error E=SâŠ•S^ğ¸direct-sumğ‘†^ğ‘†E=S\oplus\widehat{S} will satisfy the average channel constraintÂ (12). With the channel coding rate R2subscriptR2\mathrm{R}_{2} chosen according to equationÂ (17), the decoder can with high probability recover the quantized signal S^^ğ‘†\widehat{S}, and hence the message ğ¦ğ¦\mathbf{m}. Overall, the scheme allows a total of 2k2superscript2subscriptğ‘˜22^{k_{2}} distinct messages to be embedded, so that the effective information embedding rate is

Rtranssubscriptğ‘…trans\displaystyle R_{\operatorname{trans}} =\displaystyle= k2nsubscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›\displaystyle\frac{k_{2}}{n}
=\displaystyle= mâˆ’k1nâˆ’mâˆ’k1âˆ’k2nğ‘šsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›\displaystyle\frac{m-k_{1}}{n}-\frac{m-k_{1}-k_{2}}{n}
=\displaystyle= R2âˆ’R1subscriptR2subscriptR1\displaystyle\mathrm{R}_{2}-\mathrm{R}_{1}
=\displaystyle= (1âˆ’hâ€‹(p)âˆ’Ïµ/2)âˆ’(1âˆ’hâ€‹(w)+Ïµ/2)1â„ğ‘italic-Ïµ21â„ğ‘¤italic-Ïµ2\displaystyle\left(1-h\left(p\right)-\epsilon/2\right)-\left(1-h\left(w\right)+\epsilon/2\right)
=\displaystyle= hâ€‹(w)âˆ’hâ€‹(p)+Ïµ,â„ğ‘¤â„ğ‘italic-Ïµ\displaystyle h\left(w\right)-h\left(p\right)+\epsilon,

for some Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0. Thus, we have shown that the proposed scheme achieves the binary information embedding boundÂ (13). âˆ

5 Proof of source coding optimality

This section is devoted to the proof of the previously stated TheoremÂ 1 on the source coding optimality of the compound construction.

5.2 Moment analysis

In order to analyze the probability â„™â€‹[Tnâ€‹(S,â„‚;D)>0]â„™delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘†â„‚ğ·0\mathbb{P}[T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D)>0], we make use of the moment bounds given in the following elementary lemma:

Lemma 2 (Moment methods).

Given any random variable Nğ‘N taking non-negative integer values, there holds

(ğ”¼â€‹[N])2ğ”¼â€‹[N2]â‰¤(a)â„™â€‹[N>0]â‰¤(b)ğ”¼â€‹[N].superscriptğ‘superscriptğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘2â„™delimited-[]ğ‘0superscriptğ‘ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘\frac{\left(\mathbb{E}[N]\right)^{2}}{\mathbb{E}[N^{2}]}\;\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(a)}}{{\leq}}\;\mathbb{P}[N>0]\;\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(b)}}{{\leq}}\;\mathbb{E}[N]. (ğ”¼â€‹[N])2=(ğ”¼â€‹[Nâ€‹ğ•€â€‹[N>0]])2superscriptğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘2superscriptğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘ğ•€delimited-[]ğ‘02\displaystyle\left(\mathbb{E}[N]\right)^{2}\;=\;\left(\mathbb{E}\big{[}N\>\mathbb{I}[N>0]\big{]}\right)^{2} â‰¤\displaystyle\leq ğ”¼â€‹[N2]â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[ğ•€2â€‹[N>0]]=ğ”¼â€‹[N2]â€‹â„™â€‹[N>0].ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ•€2delimited-[]ğ‘0ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘2â„™delimited-[]ğ‘0\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[N^{2}]\;\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{I}^{2}[N>0]\right]\;=\;\mathbb{E}[N^{2}]\;\mathbb{P}[N>0].

âˆ

The remainder of the proof consists in applying these moment bounds to the random variable Tnâ€‹(S,â„‚;D)subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘†â„‚ğ·T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D), in order to bound the probability â„™â€‹[Tnâ€‹(S,â„‚;D)>0]â„™delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘†â„‚ğ·0\mathbb{P}[T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D)>0]. We begin by computing the first moment:

Lemma 3 (First moment).

For any code with rate Rğ‘…R, the expected number of Dğ·D-good codewords scales exponentially as

1nâ€‹logâ¡ğ”¼â€‹[Tn]1ğ‘›ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\log\mathbb{E}[T_{n}] =\displaystyle= [Râˆ’(1âˆ’hâ€‹(D))]Â±oâ€‹(1).plus-or-minusdelimited-[]R1â„ğ·ğ‘œ1\displaystyle\left[\mathrm{R}-(1-h\left(D\right))\right]\;\pm\;o(1). (26)
Proof.

First, by linearity of expectation ğ”¼â€‹[Tn]=âˆ‘i=02nâ€‹Râˆ’1â„™â€‹[Ziâ€‹(D)=1]=â€„2nâ€‹Râ€‹â„™â€‹[Z0â€‹(D)=1]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–0superscript2ğ‘›R1â„™delimited-[]superscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ·1superscript2ğ‘›Râ„™delimited-[]superscriptğ‘0ğ·1\mathbb{E}[T_{n}]=\sum_{i=0}^{2^{n\mathrm{R}}-1}\mathbb{P}[Z^{i}(D)=1]\;=\;2^{n\mathrm{R}}\mathbb{P}[Z^{0}(D)=1], where we have used symmetry of the code construction to assert that â„™â€‹[Ziâ€‹(D)=1]=â„™â€‹[Z0â€‹(D)=1]â„™delimited-[]superscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ·1â„™delimited-[]superscriptğ‘0ğ·1\mathbb{P}[Z^{i}(D)=1]=\mathbb{P}[Z^{0}(D)=1] for all indices iğ‘–i. Now the event {Z0â€‹(D)=1}superscriptğ‘0ğ·1\{Z^{0}(D)=1\} is equivalent to an i.i.d Bernoulli(12)\frac{1}{2}) sequence of length nğ‘›n having Hamming weight less than or equal to Dâ€‹nğ·ğ‘›Dn. By standard large deviations theory (either Sanovâ€™s theoremÂ [11], or direct asymptotics of binomial coefficients), we have

1nâ€‹logâ¡â„™â€‹[Z0â€‹(D)=1]1ğ‘›â„™delimited-[]superscriptğ‘0ğ·1\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\log\mathbb{P}[Z^{0}(D)=1] =\displaystyle= 1âˆ’hâ€‹(D)Â±oâ€‹(1),plus-or-minus1â„ğ·ğ‘œ1\displaystyle 1-h\left(D\right)\;\pm\;o(1),

which establishes the claim.

âˆ

Unfortunately, however, the first moment ğ”¼â€‹[Tn]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›\mathbb{E}[T_{n}] need not be representative of typical behavior of the random variable Tnsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›T_{n}, and hence overall distortion performance of the code. As a simple illustration, consider an imaginary code consisting of 2nâ€‹Rsuperscript2ğ‘›R2^{n\mathrm{R}} copies of the all-zeroes codeword. Even for this â€œcodeâ€, as long as R>1âˆ’hâ€‹(D)R1â„ğ·\mathrm{R}>1-h\left(D\right), the expected number of distortion-Dğ·D optimal codewords grows exponentially. Indeed, although Tn=0subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›0T_{n}=0 for almost all source sequences, for a small subset of source sequences (of probability mass â‰ˆ2âˆ’nâ€‹[1âˆ’hâ€‹(D)]absentsuperscript2ğ‘›delimited-[]1â„ğ·\approx 2^{-n\,\left[1-h(D)\right]}), the random variable Tnsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›T_{n} takes on the enormous value 2nâ€‹Rsuperscript2ğ‘›ğ‘…2^{nR}, so that the first moment grows exponentially. However, the average distortion incurred by using this code will be â‰ˆ0.5absent0.5\approx 0.5 for any rate, so that the first moment is entirely misleading. In order to assess the representativeness of the first moment, one needs to ensure that it is of essentially the same order as the variance, hence the comparison involved in the second moment boundÂ (25)(a).

5.3 Second moment analysis

Our analysis of the second moment begins with the following alternative representation:

Lemma 4.

6 Proof of channel coding optimality

In this section, we turn to the proof of the previously stated TheoremÂ 2, concerning the channel coding optimality of the compound construction.

If the codeword xâˆˆ{0,1}nğ‘¥superscript01ğ‘›x\in\{0,1\}^{n} is transmitted, then the receiver observes V=xâŠ•Wğ‘‰direct-sumğ‘¥ğ‘ŠV=x\oplus W, where Wğ‘ŠW is a Berâ¡(p)Berğ‘\operatorname{Ber}(p) random vector. Our goal is to bound the probability that maximum likelihood (ML) decoding fails where the probability is taken over the randomness in both the channel noise and the code construction. To simplify the analysis, we focus on the following sub-optimal (non-ML) decoding procedure. Let Ïµnsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘›\epsilon_{n} be any non-negative sequence such that Ïµn/nâ†’0â†’subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘›ğ‘›0\epsilon_{n}/n\rightarrow 0 but Ïµn2/nâ†’+âˆâ†’superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘›2ğ‘›\epsilon_{n}^{2}/n\rightarrow+\inftyâ€”say for instance, Ïµn=n2/3subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘›superscriptğ‘›23\epsilon_{n}=n^{2/3}.

Definition 2 (Decoding Rule:).

With the threshold d(n):=pn+Ïµnd(n):\,=pn+\epsilon_{n}, decode to codeword xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} â‡”iff\iff â€–xiâŠ•Vâ€–1â‰¤dâ€‹(n)subscriptnormdirect-sumsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘‰1ğ‘‘ğ‘›\|x_{i}\oplus V\|_{1}\leq d(n), and no other codeword is within dâ€‹(n)ğ‘‘ğ‘›d(n) of Vğ‘‰V.

The extra term Ïµnsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘›\epsilon_{n} in the threshold dâ€‹(n)ğ‘‘ğ‘›d(n) is chosen for theoretical convenience. Using the following two lemmas, we establish that this procedure has arbitrarily small probability of error, whence ML decoding (which is at least as good) also has arbitrarily small error probability.

With this choice, we have, for all wâˆˆ[Î½âˆ—,Î¼]ğ‘¤superscriptğœˆğœ‡w\in[\nu^{*},\mu], the sequence of inequalities

L~â€‹(w)~ğ¿ğ‘¤\displaystyle\widetilde{L}(w) â‰¤\displaystyle\leq Rh(Î¼)âˆ’D(p||Î´âˆ—(Î½âˆ—;dc)âˆ—p)\displaystyle Rh\left(\mu\right)-D\left(p||\delta^{*}(\nu^{*};d_{c})\ast p\right)

which completes the proof.

âˆ

7 Discussion

In this paper, we established that it is possible to achieve both the rate-distortion bound for symmetric Bernoulli sources and the channel capacity for the binary symmetric channel using codes with bounded graphical complexity. More specifically, we have established that there exist low-density generator matrix (LDGM) codes and low-density parity check (LDPC) codes with finite degrees that, when suitably compounded to form a new code, are optimal for both source and channel coding. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first demonstration of classes of codes with bounded graphical complexity that are optimal as source and channel codes simultaneously. We also demonstrated that this compound construction has a naturally nested structure that can be exploited to achieve the Wyner-Ziv boundÂ [45] for lossy compression of binary data with side information, as well as the Gelfand-Pinsker boundÂ [19] for channel coding with side information.

Since the analysis of this paper assumed optimal decoding and encoding, the natural next step is the development and analysis of computationally efficient algorithms for encoding and decoding. Encouragingly, the bounded graphical complexity of our proposed codes ensures that they will, with high probability, have high girth and good expansion, thus rendering them well-suited to message-passing and other efficient decoding procedures. For pure channel coding, previous workÂ [16, 36, 41] has analyzed the performance of belief propagation when applied to various types of compound codes, similar to those analyzed in this paper. On the other hand, for pure lossy source coding, our own past workÂ [44] provides empirical demonstration of the feasibility of modified message-passing schemes for decoding of standard LDGM codes. It remains to extend both these techniques and their analysis to more general joint source/channel coding problems, and the compound constructions analyzed in this paper.

Appendix A Basic property of LDGM codes

Appendix B Bounds on binomial coefficients

The following bounds on binomial coefficients are standard (see Chap. 12,Â [11]):

hâ€‹(kn)âˆ’logâ¡(n+1)nâ‰¤1nâ€‹logâ¡(nk)â‰¤hâ€‹(kn).â„ğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘›1ğ‘›1ğ‘›binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜â„ğ‘˜ğ‘›h\left(\frac{k}{n}\right)-\frac{\log(n+1)}{n}\;\leq\;\frac{1}{n}\log{n\choose k}\;\leq\;h\left(\frac{k}{n}\right). (46)

Here, for Î±âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in(0,1), the quantity h(Î±):=âˆ’Î±logÎ±âˆ’(1âˆ’Î±)log(1âˆ’Î±)h(\alpha):\,=-\alpha\log\alpha-(1-\alpha)\log(1-\alpha) is the binomial entropy function.
